												OutDrive, in one way, is an amazing achievement, and DENVER has a lot to be proud of with their creation. I mean that. The screenshots simply do not do this game any level of justice, as there's actually a lot of varied scenary to keep things fresh and thus never feels like the "empty sunset highway" some people have voiced concern over before buying. The combination of audio/visual elements delivers THE best 80's/neon/VHS/vaporwave experience I've ever seen in a video game, hands down.There is so much attention put into everything, from the tastefully low polygon count on most of the assets, to the bloom that glows softly off of the neon and the post-processing filter across the screen, it all ensures that this game feels like a 3D interactive vaporwave poster art. As a work of art, it's meticulously crafted and feels SO good to play for the first few minutes. Alas, the art style is not the aforementioned achievement displayed in this product, because it's just ripping off of the upcoming Kickstarter-funded game Power Drive 2000. Seriously, look up some screenshots and try not to feel insulted on behalf of PD2k's developers. Even if you're someone who's really into the whole vaporwave/vhs aesthetic, this game is not worth the price of admission as it's just a petty clone/cashgrab feeding itself off of the Power Drive hype. I want to make it clear that I do not hate this game for not being Power Drive, because I had no idea what Power Drive was until after I  played this game and read some of the user reviews. I have zero attachment to that project, and my opinion is not in comparison to that game, but how the game stands on its own merit in a world where it was actually an original idea.The problem with OutDrive is that, beyond stimulating your eyes and ears, there is NOTHING left. At its most basic level, the game mechanics are actually quite good, which makes it even more confusing that nothing interesting was done with them. Driting around sharper turns is fun, hitting the ramp between roadblocks is fun, balancing speed with trying not to overheat keeps you engaged as you drive. And yet, absolutely none of these things provide you with any real challenge. My FIRST run in the game lasted 28 minutes and the only reason I stopped was because I was BORED, not because I failed. Despite having a meter that forces you to go fast but not too fast, I spun out, came to a COMPLETE halt, hit the (unlimited) boost, and was back on my way without penalty. It's borderline insulting. There are so many great ideas here that just don't do anything meaningful. If you're driving through a city (which looks ♥♥♥♥ing SICK, by the way) you may have to dodge cross-traffic or some of the lanes may have a car driving alongside you. It would have been so easy to use this as an opportunity to challenge the players environmental awareness as they have to watch the road ahead of them, and dodge the cars beside them, and yet these other cars are separated by wide distance, predictable, and easily avoided. Likewise, there is a helicopter that shows up once in a while to fire bullets at you, which literally just bounce off your car when you do get hit, there is no consequence for this whatsoever. Sometimes, the chopper will try missiles instead, which hit the road ahead of you, bringing up chunks of pavement that you may crash into if you're not careful. While these missiles are the hardest part of the game, they are by no means a threat, considering even if you get hit by a big slab of the road and find yourself turned 180 degrees, all you have to do is quickly press that boost, turn around, and you're on your way before your speed meter ever reaches the bottom.If you want to jam out to some downtempo 80's-esque electronic synth music while dining on a visual feast, go for it, but do not expect the game to challenge you in any way. It's an endless runner that somehow screwed up the most necessary part of the genre: losing. And that's one hell of an achievement to be proud of.

 Overview  OutDrive is a time-based, retro driving game where you must maintain a relatively constant speed in order to keep your girlfriend alive. During the introductory scene, you face off with three unknown assailants with terrible aim, who miss you entirely and strike your girlfriend in the chest. With instructions given from your on-dash computer, you install a makeshift terminal to her heart and drive off into the sunset. End scene.With that being the whole plot of OutDrive, we're left with little else to go by. Now, I can get past a subpar story if the game is well made, but the key, untold aspects of who we are, who those people were and why I can perform heart surgery on a whim are just the beginning. OutDrive is truly a dull, pointless game to play.With no key binding options available, pushing play will start the game immediately, without any formal instructions or direction, nor any prompts telling you what the controls are. You're left with ten seconds to figure it out before you lose and have to restart. Now, restarting isn't a big deal since there is little purpose to starting in the first place; however, once you begin cruising along, your mission is to maintain your high rate of speed to keep your nameless girlfriend alive, keeping the engine running between "too slow" and "too fast". Driving too slow will kill your girlfriend, driving too fast, in theory, would do the same, but it doesn't. You can hammer down the throttle and suffer no consequences, despite what the game tells you.Driving in OutDrive is cumbersome and feels unnaturally stiff and heavy. Your car flip-flops between feeling like go-kart and a truck with no power steering; hitting curbs or boundaries will cause your heart meter to fade drastically and often send your car flying in a seemingly random direction [if you're lucky you'll crash in the tunnels and clip through the terrain]. After some practice, I was able to control the car appropriately, but after mastering the controls, there wasn't much else do to. The game states the track "never ends", which to date nobody can prove otherwise, removing a satisfying ending from the mix; so you're left wandering aimlessly down the track, dodging other vehicles, jumping ramps and taking sharp turns and hoping you run into some fun along the way.On the store page it hints at something interesting at the eight minute mark, stating: "P.S. Try to hold out for 8 minutes...", which, once you get there, becomes a major disappointment. A neon helicopter descends from the sky, firing mini guns and rockets, creating the first and only burst of energy the game could muster. However, after 30 seconds the helicopter randomly explodes, leaving just you and your thoughts alone until the next eight minute marker and its inevitable return.The longest I drove was around the 36:00 minute mark before realizing I was just wasting time, expecting entertainment and adventure from a game that has none. As the realization set in and I started to think of everything else I could be doing with my time, I crashed into a wall, died and shut it off. OutDrive does just what it says: it drives you out of the game.   Pros   The music is well done for the most part. There are a few uncomfortably long delays in the tracks sometimes, which can be annoying. Cons    No defined plot of purpose. Major mechanical issues with "overheating".  No difficulty progression after the eight minute mark. No key rebinding, no score keeping.Overall, OutDrive is a hollow, shell of what a game really could be; with boring backgrounds, clunky steering, no purpose and no story, OutDrive is nothing more than an 80s mix tape that you listen to while smashing the space button until your fingers hurt.

												Before I purchased the game I seen all of these negative reviews and wondered why. The Gameplay looks pretty good, the music is amazing, and the graphics are pretty nice to look at. When I purchased the game and played it for a little... I soon found out why. Now don't get me wrong, the game is pretty cool and fun to play, however there are absolutely no options for the game. no raising or lowering the sound, no changing controls, not even any other game mode options. All you do is pretty much drive. Your goal is to get a high score which I feel shouldn't be it main focus, especially if you're trying to keep a girl alive! Speaking about her, I feel like she's not even there, sure the meter tells us how she’s doing but other than that we get no dialogue from her or the driver, we don't even get to see what they look like in game. Now I've seen some people encounter a lot of glitches, however I didn't have this problem to an extreme. My game glitched out only once and it was for crashing into an oncoming car. I also feel a like there is a lack of action, only a little bit though. There are cars that come after you and a Helicopter that guns you down, but those are in very small sections, after you pass the sections they're gone. Then it's a dead, lonely, empty road. At least have a few cop cars chase for a bit in those sections, really make it like I'm the game, that there is a purpose, to make me feel hype.  I feel like this game should have some kind of story behind it, I mean how you like a movie where the person just drives to keep this girl alive, no ending. At least stay focused on the story and makes the high score part a secondary game mode. Do I recommend the game? No, not unless there do some serious updating, if you're interested buy it on sale.

Teal DeerDevelopers: DenverPublishers: ASK Games Initial release: Feb 2016Genre: Driving, Casual#Worth/NotWorth: #Worth Exposition, Concurrence and SummationFULL DISCLOSUREI paid nothing for this. It was a giveaway thing. As such the following will be written from that perspective.Outdrive is a game that is almost not a game. It has some loose narrative in that your girlfriend gets shot and you must 'out drive' the the 'bad dudes' in order to save her and presumably get her to a hospital, if such a thing even exists in the retro neon dystopia of the far flung future. The juxtaposition here is that there is no hospital. For what seems a procedurally generated track, the actual game is really just an endurance run with a timer. You must use boost to keep the car at speed designated by the blue bar directly behind the car. Go to fast or go to slow. She dies. Now, the music in this game is actually quite decent. Its mindless and very relaxing. The tempo decreases and gets distorted when your car is not going at speed. Which is a bit disappointing for relaxing aspect of it but its no matter really. I had a hell of time trying to get a gamepad to actually do anything worth while. Trying two 3rd party programs as well as just setting the key bindings in the setup utility. I eventually settled on just WASD'ing my way through it. I'm no stickler for peoples preferred control method but certain genres beg a specific control scheme. Either way WASD works well enough for this task.The car physics are extremely suspect as well. A gentle tap on the wall will send you spinning and usually end up facing the other way. It seems once the car leaves the ground it weighs less than a piece of paper. At one point I started driving sideways on the invisible boundary of the track and a helicopter knocked me off and I was able to drive out of bounds a short while until I was blasted into the sky and juggled for a bit until my girlfriend died. 


I'm pretty sure I broke it

												Outrun and its sequels are arcade classics. This is a series that's all about driving all over the world in an expensive sports car. It's just you, the road, and the love of your life. Even when you're not behind the wheel of a Ferrari, your car has the top down, so both the driver and the passenger are visible. This is a minor detail, but it really adds to the sense of escapism. In Outrun 2, the girlfriend is very expressive, cheering on your successful driving skills, and getting annoyed when you bump into cars. While it's easy to say that the Outrun games are great, due to their fantastic controls and solid game-design, it's the tone and atmosphere that really bring it all together.Outdrive is...well I'm going to be serious here. Outdrive is a twisted metaphor for keeping a loved-one on life-support. In the intro, your girlfriend is shot during a hired hit, a drug deal gone bad, or actually... nevermind. The reason is irrelevant. Basically, she's going to die, and there's nothing you can do about it. Even knowing this, you hook her up to your car's engine to keep her alive. This isn't a temporary measure; you aren't going to get her to the hospital or anything. The purpose of this game is to drive for as long as possible, until you either go too slow, too fast, or realize the futility of it all and pull the plug.I hate to go on a moral tangent in a videogame review, but I'm just calling it like I see it. After hooking your girlfriend up to your car, the only signs of life she exhibits are open eyes and in-between songs you can hear some breathing. Granted, she was mortally wounded only minutes ago, but she's already in what could be considered a vegetative state. It would be different if she spoke, or showed some awareness. Maybe she would talk about what happened, use her last moments to reflect upon better times, etc. It's not like her condition will improve, so why do this? So the two of you can sit in silence and listen to synth-music while looking at the neon li-everything?Oh right, the game portion, I nearly forgot to talk about this. In short, the controls are awful. As the other reviews have stated, keyboard-only is the way to go, because you have to constantly boost to keep the girl alive. For whatever reason, the gamepad doesn't function properly. Steering is problematic, and drifting sends you into just as many walls as not-drifting. Oddly enough, your speed doesn't actually matter. As long as you have your finger on the boost, and are making at least some forward (and sometimes even backward!) progress, then the girl will stay "alive". It's entirely possible to drive at 10-15 mph and it wouldn't affect anything. After about eight and a half minutes, a helicopter appears to shoot at you. This can cause debris to block your path, but it's mostly ineffective. Although, I will point out that the first time the girl died was because I got stuck in debris, the car flipped upside-down, and everything started spazzing out.By the way, when your girlfriend dies, the game says that you killed her. What? Maybe it's the driver finally accepting the inevitable, and realizing he was wrong to put someone he cares about in such a dangerous situation in the first place. You can also hit the "r" key at any time. This is considered the kill button. Now I'm not even sure what the game's intentions are supposed to be. Pressing the "r" key causes the game to instantly restart, and you don't recieve a "You killed her" message for that. This is what I get for reading too far into things, because now the game is just throwing me for a loop. By the way, if you're driving too fast or slow, your girlfriend will suffer from intense pain. Yes, the game posts a message saying as much whenever you restart.Outdrive isn't just a bad driving game, it's also really depressing. What's the point of playing this game for a long period of time? To brag to others that you kept a dying person alive - possibly against their will - for an hour or two? This is nothing more than a hollow and extremely selfish accomplishment. Just let her go. It's difficult to accept, but it's better this way. I don't mean to delve into these serious subjects, but within minutes of playing, the realization hit me, and I started to feel absolutely horrible. Nobody deserves to be treated like this.So.... yeah... Anyone up for a game of CrotchFighter?

												GNARLY GAME -- and not in a good way.You can only play OutDrive using keyboard controls, which are overly sensitive, so your car turns 90 degrees into a wall if you're not very, very careful. Maintaining control of the car is difficult given how keys have been mapped -- very cramped. You can re-map the controls, but this kind of game really needs controller support. In this day and age, for this type of game, not including PROPER controller support is just lazy.And for those of you that say that you CAN use a controller ... well, it is not working properly for me. For example, when using the boost, which you absolutely need for this game, I can see it's working, but the game doesn't seem to recognize it, so I die anyway.To survive, you must keep your speed within a certain band -- you can't drive too slow or too fast for extended periods or game over. I can understand a mechanism that encourages the player not to go too slow, but too fast is a problem ...? Totally lame mechanism.Final verdict: 1/10 - Not rad. The 1 point is for style and graphics, but lack of substance.I was hoping for an OutRun-like game ... simplistic but enjoyable driving, but OutDrive is not fun at all. Don't be swayed by the cool graphics, which are definitely amazing. But the game itself is boring and frustrating, with terrible controls. Classic case of a game that have some interesting ideas and looks gorgeous, but fails in execution and gameplay. OutDrive does not deserve your money when so many better games are out there.

												OutDrive is a relaxing game that is great to play in the background while you talk to friends. The retro landscape and music is nice, and it's easy to be lulled into a calm space.That being said, this game is very repetitive. Once you've played for 7 minutes, you've played the entire game. The track you drive on is one big loop, and nothing every changes. If you crash, it is very easy to start going again before you fail (where you clearly should), so there is virtually no challenge to this game. This game offers very rudimentary car physics, and it's easy to spin out from tapping the edge of the map or going from 0 to 60 in a way that just feels off. This game offers poor controller support, although, with the steam controller, it can be configured. Other than that, there is no way to edit the controls.At $2.99, this game is not worth it. I got it in a sale for $0.30 and I'm happy with that. If it goes on sale, I'd recommend it. At $2.99, buying it will leave you full of regret.

Posted: May 10, 2016
												I remember when I was a kid playing games like Pole Position and some other great arcade and Nintendo racing games, some of which I can't remember the names of anymore. During the SNES years, it was Top Gear. Anyway, I remember my dad commenting a time or two about how it bothered him that in these racing games, you have this background that you're heading to, but never seem to actuly get to. The background never tessellates. I remember, at like 10 years old, explaining to my dad that the point of the game was the race, not to actuly "get anywhere," and the background was just an esthetic choice by the artists that had nothing to do with the game's core mechanics. My pops agreed with this, but said it would be cool if you could get to the mysterious city looming in the far background. This struck me as strangely magical thinking for a guy who rarely played video games, who usually spent his days with invoices, groceries, dishwasher repairs, and other boring adult stuff I still don't care about, and probably that is why the idea of "getting to the background" stuck in my head for many years. And I'm not the only one, apparently. Games like Grand Theft Auto 5 represent the full experience of the long drive that actuly gets you to the background. Magic. I thought about that a lot after activating Trevor in GTA5, and the game makes you take that LONG drive from the background into the part of the game you were just in on Franklin. Epic. Thought provoking. But one of those thoughts is, In this rush to make these hyper-advanced sandbox games that let us do all these things we dreamed of doing in less-interactive games for years, have we ignored the simpler, more pure and patient pleasures offered us by older games, have we neglected updating that simple experience in favor of games that really just have TOO much going on in them sometimes? Enter the new generation of "retro" games, with new graphics and sound, but with more pure game-play elements than the standard "do whatever you want and get a trophy for everything" style that the console industry churns out by the billions these days. Out Drive is one of those games. There is no where to "get to," once you're there you just win. But the GAME itself is driving, just DRIVING. Driving with a sense of urgency, not to get anywhere in the game, but to GET somewhere inside yourself. Plumb the depths of your skills. There is no real plot, you just HAVE. TO. DRIVE. You're already where you're getting to. Just. Drive.

												OutDrive is almost a great experience (ALMOST). The aesthetic is of course top tier and the music is great as always new age synth. In this respect it feels like FarCry: Blood Dragon mixed with the movie Drive and that is a stylistic match made in heaven. These music and visuals are both pretty solid qualities of the game but unfortunately what supports these aspects are nowhere near as impressive. You simply drive in OutDrive, it's a procedurally generated driving game in which you just have to keep moving within a certain speed range or else you fail. Sometimes there's some random events that happen but that literally just consists of either brief oncoming traffic or an attack helicopter that tries to shoot you. These are handled pretty well for the most part and I don't mind a game in which you just drive but there is a real lack of content here, even for a game that's £2. There are no online leader boards or particular diversity to each playthrough. Despite technically driving through a unique path each time, it barely feels any different and having only a couple of short random events just leaves me slightly unsatisfied. However there are two major problems with the game that render the rest unimportant. The game performs horrendously, this will likely be one of the most demanding indie games you play. It's surprising how good of a rig you will need in order to run this game at 60FPS, it even struggles to maintain 30FPS on a PC that can run most big releases on mid-low settings. Another problem in terms of optimization is crashes, I've had this game crash 4 times on me completely out of nowhere and I've heard similar complaints from other Steam users. The second major problem would be the controls, the car just doesn't handle well at all. It feels rigid and clunky, I fail to see how such a key aspect of a driving game was made so poorly. While it's possible to overcome the bad car handling to an extent, you'll never feel as though it plays the way it should.I really wanted to like this game and from a visual and audio standpoint I absolutely do. I even think many tracks from the OST will be ones I'll listen to outside of the game. But a lack of diversity, lack of real content, lack of optimization and lack of decent controls stop me from being able to recommend this game. Don't bother with the game at all, even if you see it for free just don't get it.Scores:Audio & music : 8/10Visuals: 8/10Gameplay: 3/10Optimisation & performance: 2/10Value (at full price): 5/10Final verdict: 4/10 AVOID COMPLETELY!!!

												OutDrive reminds me of my old casette player back in '95. It was broken so I had to hold the "Play" button to listen to the music I was into. On one hand it made me feel uncomfortable, on the other - I had great time listening to my favourite tracks. Same kind of feeling I have with OutDrive - the gameplay is bad, at point I can say this is hardly a game at all. Your DeLorean handling is awful, physics are non-existent and there's no controller support (for the game like this - almost a crime). The other big problem I had is the lack of any motivation to play. There's no rewards - no achievements, no ladder to compare your results with other players, no story (I don't count the intro movie), no new cars or new maps. nothing. If you add the fact OutDrive is too easy - you'll have no problem getting over 20+ minutes in single run. I can't say graphics is good, cause it is not. But the design is good - lots of neon and polygon-like surronding give this 80's feeling. The part game shines - is the music (not the sounds - they are bad). The OST consists of synth/retro-wave tracks and there are LOTS of them (played for 3 hours and heard the same music once or twice). So if you're a fan of the genre (like I am) you'll have good time listening to it.Just like i said - OutDrive reminds me of my old casette player, except it's not broken. It's hard to really accept OutDrive as a game, cause it feels more like WinAmp visualization came to life. Can i recommend it? Yes, if you're into that genre of music. For the price it's awesome deal.If you want good racing game and not a BIG fan of such visuals or music - stay away. You'll get bitter aftertaste.

												The aesthetics of the game are spot on 80s.  Everything is bright blue and purple neon--even the car model used is the quintessentially 80s DeLorean DMC-12. And the music is perfect period synth-pop, excellently composed.The "story" is as follows. You're some kind of wheelman for some shady people and the S goes down. Your girl takes a bullet for your sorry butt and somehow (it's not really explained how this works) you connect your car's engine to your girlfriend's heart, which apparently keeps her heart beating. You drive for as long as possible until you foul up. You foul up, the girl dies and the stage ends.  There is no end stage--you go until you can't go any further, then try again to go farther. There really isn't much to this game.The controls are awkward and not customizable, and there is no gamepad support as of this writing (2/23/16).You boost to go faster (by holding LShift) and you'll need to be boosting most of the time. Being off boost means the meter that follows your car drops. Dropping too low (to the left) means your girl starts to die--her heart slows down, the music distorts and everything goes gray.  Going too far to the right makes the car overheat (which isn't doing your dying girlfriend any favors either). Roadblocks, jumps and attack choppers will all attempt to slow you down on the endless winding road.As I said, the controls are awkward.   WASD to control the car, arrows to control the camera (you will almost never need to use these) LShift to boost and Space to drift.  The WASD controls mean your pinky is left to the boost button, and as I said before you'll be on boost more than you're off. This gets really tiring after a few minutes and it's needlessly awkward.The game is unsubstantial and could use some extremely basic additions (like gamepad support, or even the ability to remap controls).  I can't recommend this game at full price. In fact even for what I paid ($1.79) I'm not sure if it's worth the money.

												Tl:DR: It looks great, sounds great, but is held back by mechanical weakness. Story:Outdrive is a game about driving (unsuprisingly). The story outlines a nameless man who gets in trouble with some other nameless men, leading to the first mans girl getting shot and now the only thing he can do to save her is hook her heart up to the engine and keep on driving so she can keep on living. Essentially, the story is very week and should not really be bothered with.Sound:The music in this game is fantastic, no other way to put it. It really helps bring out the neon 80's aesthetic and doesn't get old too fast. The sound effects are serviceable but are nothing special and the acceleration effect can become irritating after awhile.Graphics:Another thing the game does well is visually present itself. It looks great and the color scheme is perfect for the atmosphere the devs were shooting for. As a side note the launcher itself could have a few more presets. Even though it's a unity game it would be nice to have 8x AA without forcing vsync on as well.Controls:The controls in OutDrive aren't terrible but they don't necessarily feel good. The steering feels rigid and the drifting can be quite fiddly at times, which many times ends up with you smashing into the invisible barriers alongside the road.Gameplay:This is my major gripe with this game. Now, first let me clarify that I understand that the devs were not trying to develop a "game" persay, more of an "experiment" or "aesthetic concept" as the description puts it. That being said, that doesn't excuse OutDrive from having a mechanic that really irritates me and that really is a shame because funnily enough, it's one of the only mechanics in the game. The mechanic in question is the fact that you have to balance out your speed so that your girls heart (which is hooked up to the motor) doesn't overheat or get damaged. On paper this sounds like an excellent idea and I can kind of see where they were going with it. However it means that you can never buildup speed and you must constantly slow down to make sure that your girl doesn't die and end the game. There is also almost no obstacles anywhere and even cornering is ridculously easy due to the slow speed you are forced to move at. 												The aesthetics of the game are spot on 80s.  Everything is bright blue and purple neon--even the car model used is the quintessentially 80s DeLorean DMC-12. And the music is perfect period synth-pop, excellently composed.The "story" is as follows. You're some kind of wheelman for some shady people and the S goes down. Your girl takes a bullet for your sorry butt and somehow (it's not really explained how this works) you connect your car's engine to your girlfriend's heart, which apparently keeps her heart beating. You drive for as long as possible until you foul up. You foul up, the girl dies and the stage ends.  There is no end stage--you go until you can't go any further, then try again to go farther. There really isn't much to this game.The controls are awkward and not customizable, and there is no gamepad support as of this writing (2/23/16).You boost to go faster (by holding LShift) and you'll need to be boosting most of the time. Being off boost means the meter that follows your car drops. Dropping too low (to the left) means your girl starts to die--her heart slows down, the music distorts and everything goes gray.  Going too far to the right makes the car overheat (which isn't doing your dying girlfriend any favors either). Roadblocks, jumps and attack choppers will all attempt to slow you down on the endless winding road.As I said, the controls are awkward.   WASD to control the car, arrows to control the camera (you will almost never need to use these) LShift to boost and Space to drift.  The WASD controls mean your pinky is left to the boost button, and as I said before you'll be on boost more than you're off. This gets really tiring after a few minutes and it's needlessly awkward.The game is unsubstantial and could use some extremely basic additions (like gamepad support, or even the ability to remap controls).  I can't recommend this game at full price. In fact even for what I paid ($1.79) I'm not sure if it's worth the money.

												I see why this product has mixed reviews.The game itself is meh.The graphics are great and all the animations are very true to the 80's era.The soundtrack itself was worth playing for an hour or so as well since I'm heavily into the 80's retro synth genre.Unfortunately if your car so much as slows down too much or bumps into a wall or obstacle, this wonderful music gets interrupted with a very VHS style sound glitch(this is intentional as a design element, mind you).This wouldn't be that bad if you could maybe turn it off but you can't. The novelty of this wears of very quickly when wanting to just listen to the music, though.The controls are somewhat slippery and while they're not that hard to pick up, there seems to be no real option for recovery whenever you make a hard crash. Your only option is to just restart the level.It's priced normally at $3 but isn't even worth that much.The best thing I walked away with was the new set of tunes I'll be jamming to in the near future. Ironically enough I feel like this was the REAL purpose of this game. Not to make a decent little quickie you could pick up but more so to expose these retro synth artists(none of which I've even heard of until now funny enough) and get music sales going.How am I so sure? It's a part of the main menu, lol.You want a good 80' style racing game? Sorry. It ain't here.Hopefully that will be Power Drive 2000(the game this one clearly ripped off).You want some good 80's style retro synth tunes? 												OutDrive is simply "all style, no substance". The synthwave aesthetic, graphics and music make the game look promising from the trailer, however, those are probably the only redeeming qualities it has. Going fast isn't a requirement either - driving at a snails pace while maintaining the arrow is also completely acceptable. There are pretty much no limitations or any actual challenge besides that, and on top of that there's only a few pieces of scenery put together into an endless track, most of which you see within about 15 minutes of playing. All of that mixed together with unresponsive menus, slow loading times, weird controls and handling make it hard to recommend it as a game. It could have had potential to be better with any kind of incentive to play, but all it's worth amounts to free trading cards.

PROS+The visuals are amazing, and perfectly 80s. I kept slowing down just to watch a section of terrain roll past, and the opening cinematic had a great 80s-noire feel to it. I half expected the car to ask me if I was a bad enough dude to save the girlfriend.+The music is phenomenal, though I wish you could control it at all.CONS-There is literally nothing to do in this game but drive. The only obstacles are turns and jumps, and because of how terrible the controls and handling are these obstacles will usually end the game.-The car handles like a brick on crisco. While holding forward it shimmies left and right for no reason, even on straightaways. While drifting (the only other control in the game) the tires' friction spikes and drops randomly, meaning you need to mash left and right to avoid slamming into a wall.- Touching a wall at all is like running headfirst into a tree. There's no grinding around a curve, you just get slammed to a stop and, usually, turned around. At one point my car flipped on its side, and the game decided that was my new road. I was only able to drive straight up into the air until the meter dropped and the game ended.- There's no validation on the randomly-generated road. A jump can spawn that fires you directly into the wall, at which point you get to choose whether you hit the barricade and lose or take the jump and lose.SUMMARYThe game is, unfortunately, not fun. It looks and sounds awesome, but the gameplay designer seriously dropped the ball here. I understand it wasn't meant to be a game, just an "aesthetic concept", but the bugs and shoddy controls ruin the experience completely.PS: After 8min there's a couple more obstacles: a helicopter and a city street. The heli shoots at you (which does nothing) and fires rockets that spin you around and throw chunks of debris onto the street. Neither is too bad, but if a chunk of debris lands on you while you're spun out you can't turn around in time to avoid losing. Heli spawns every 8min. City street materializes cars in front of you that act like walls. Still not really worth the time.

												Possibly the only endless runner game I'll ever play. Despite the controversy around the game that seems to be brewing in the community, the game itself is a pretty relaxing affair with some very stylised and fitting 80's inspired synth-heavy music. Visuals are great and hypnotic and it's pretty nice to just phase out and take it all in. However, the game does play like a poor man's, bare bones Distance. The gameplay is very limited and would probably bore most gamers after 10 or so minutes.However, I have fallen oddly in love with the game. Game would be a lot better if the controller setting were a little more optimised, as using the WASD keys and SPACE to drift around counters does feel a little clunky. I'm pretty sure most of the keys are mapped, but I find that the boost button is off, patch that and I'll be happy.Vaporwave update, when?

												OutDrive is an aesthetically beautiful game, with an atmospheric soundtrack that will pull you into the game albeit the game's mechanics need lots of work. Keeping up with the speed you're supposed to drive at isn't tough but it is awfully distracting when you bump into walls and the soundtrack slows down. The best part about this game is the audio, and to punish the player by pulling them out of the amazing soundtrack they were listening to only because they drifted incorrectly is a terrible mechanic. If they can rework that single problem, I wouldn't mind holding my WASD/space keys down for an hour on this neon lit road towards the neon sun. OutDrive doesn't have controller support  yet, and the game's resolution is a bit hard to get right. I hope that the developers intend to fix this soon because I would love to play this game often. Although I didn't live through the 80's, it definitely has that vibe, and if you enjoyed Hotline Miami, you'll enjoy this game. OutDrive has a lot of potential, and it's a must buy for the current price. The soundtrack itself is worth much more than that, and so are the aesthetics. I can't wait to see how much the game will improve over the course of this year.

												There's a strong battle between pros and cons with this game. I'm recommending it simply because the developer did put  time in creating this game. He used his skills to get the word out about some new song artists that are trying to make it in this world. However, there's a lot of room for improvement. This game seems to be more about the music rather than the actual controls or gameplay. The pros:-Colorful, and alive background-Good music-Good concept/story-Cool, easy to use UI-Easy to pick up/redirect yourself if you get stuck (usually)-I do like the concept of when your car stops or crashes, the screen dims (her life is ending if you don't get yer sh#t together man!) and the music slows down. The music will also speed up when your car is overheating.-The "life" meter is simple to follow, but has room for improvement. The cons:-The car (controls) does not handle so well at times. (Sometimes if you hit the wall, your car will spin all the way around, but a pro is that you can easily redirect it) It feels like you're skating on ice.-Hard to see road blocks (You may not have enough time to react to it)-Having to redo your settings each time you start up the game (gamers usually like their setup to be remembered)The developer himself mentions above that this isn't technically a game, but more so a music/aesthetic experiement. I do believe that this "game" has a potential to actually be a game though. If the developer focuses on fixing it or tuning it, I will definitely play more of it in the future. As I said, the concept is very cool. I also believe the game would be better if we didn't have to worry so much about hitting the walls. You run into them quite frequently. (Or maybe I'm just that clumsy?) But I suppose it's better than falling off the track every 30 seconds.Now if you're looking for an inexpensive way to listen to music and enjoy some neon scenery, here you go. Note: You DO see the helicopter in the game (I found it about 7-8 minutes into my ride, but it isn't too threatening).
